title: Hello World
text:
The below R code takes the phrase ‚ÄúHello World!‚Äù and prints it to the console. It‚Äôs a good way to check you are set up correctly!








The above code block is interactive so you can use it to test small bits of code. Anything you write will not be saved.
Once you‚Äôve checked that‚Äôs working, copy and paste it into an R file in RStudio. To run it, you want to highlight the line and click the run button.


RStudio is split into the following four panels:

Top-left: Create and edit your R programming files
Top-right: See your data (tables and values)
Bottom-left: Console to run one or two lines of code
Bottom-right: View your folders and plots (different tabs)

Top panels





Code Editor








Environment




Bottom panels





Console








Files and Plots










Note



RStudio by default only runs the line you‚Äôve selected. To run, you‚Äôll need to highlight both lines and click ‚ÄúRun‚Äù, or click the arrow next to ‚ÄúRun‚Äù and select ‚ÄúRun all‚Äù which will run all the code in your file.


The variable you create will appear in the top right panel. What value does it have? Is this what you expect?
The result of the code will also appear in the console bottom left panel.

title: Careers
text:
Careers
R programming is a skill that comes in useful in many careers. These careers may include:

Bioinformatician
Data analyst
Data scientist
Forensic statistician
Clinical trail R programming lead

Here is a snapshot of some (shortened) job adverts from 2025 - check out the person requirements:
If you find you particulary enjoy this course, you can also check out the following internships, graduate schemes and masters degrees.
Not sure what you want to do? No problem - you‚Äôre still at an early stage in your degree. You might change your mind quite a few times between now and then! But it‚Äôs always worth thinking about what you might like to do and anything you need to do to get there.

title: Error messages
text:
Error messages
Programming code is it‚Äôs own language, but with really strict grammar. If I mistakes make in sentrances, like I do in this one, you can still understand the meaning.
If we make a mistake in code, even a typo, the computer will not understand.
However, it does try to be helpful. We get an Error message in the console (bottom left panel) that gives us a clue as to what the problem is.
Try with the below code. What does the error message say? Can you try and fix it?

title: R functions
text:
R functions
We won‚Äôt be writing our own R functions, but we‚Äôll be using in-built functions and functions from libraries.
A function is like a mini-program - it‚Äôs a set of code that somebody else has written that we can apply to our own variables.
These work using the following structure: function_name(arguments) where:

function_name is the name of the function
arguments are the values we are putting in, or any options we want to change

See examples below using some in-built functions:








We can also give multiple arguments by separating them with commas.
In the example below, we‚Äôre using the seq() function to generate a sequence of numbers. We want the sequence to start at 0, end at 20, and go up by 2 every number.









Give it a go:
From what you‚Äôve learnt so far, can you:

Generate every third number from 1 to 100 (1, 3, 6‚Ä¶)
Find the mean of those numbers
Find the standard deviation
















NoteHint 1





Consider using the seq() function

seq(start value, stop value, by=increase)












NoteHint 2





Consider using the functions seq(), mean() and sd()

variablename <- seq(start value, stop value, by=increase)
mean(variablename)
sd(variablename)

title: Unpaired t-test
text:
We‚Äôre going to be using the same examples as in Statistics lecture 3 for each of our tests.


The first thing we need to do is copy our data in R. As these are fairly small datasets, we can manually type in our data using the c() function to create a vector of values.











We can use the summary() function to see our mean and interquartile range for each set of values.











Using the function t.test(), we can add our two sets of values as arguments and calculate the p-value. This should match the result from excel.








That‚Äôs our t-test done already!
We didn‚Äôt have to use any options here as the default test is two tailed, unpaired, and assuming the variance is not equal. If you want to change any of the options, you can try:

alternative for two tailed or one tailed

‚Äútwo.sided‚Äù for a two tailed test,
‚Äúgreater‚Äù for one tailed where the mean of the first variable is greater than the mean of the second variable
‚Äúless‚Äù for one tailed where the mean of the first variable is greater than the mean of the second variable
unpaired_t_test_result <- t.test(NonDiabetic, Diabetic, alternative="greater")

paired for paired or unpaired

TRUE for paired
FALSE for unpaired
unpaired_t_test_result <- t.test(NonDiabetic, Diabetic, paired = TRUE)

mu mean, for comparison for a one-tailed test




We can use the following code to create a dataframe with the above vectors.
We need a column that contains the correct group - ‚ÄúNonDiabetic‚Äù or ‚ÄúDiabetic‚Äù for each value. We can use the rep() function for this which replicates values.

c("NonDiabetic", "Diabetic") is a list of the items we want to repeat
each = 16 gives us a list of 16 of each. We could also put c(16,16).












We can now create a boxplot in the same way we did in Tutorial 1. We can also add a t-test result using the function stat_compare_means() from the ggpubr package.











We‚Äôve just turned our two lists into one long dataframe, but what if we want to do the opposite?
If you want to extract the values for a particular group, we can use the following structure:








If you look in your environment, DiabeticExtracted should be identical to your Diabetic values.
Using this, if you are importing data from excel you can extract the values into groups to prepare for your t-test.

title: Vectors
text:
Vectors
After variables, the next thing we need to understand is vectors.
Vectors are a bit like lists but they can only hold one type of variable such as all integers (whole numbers) or all strings (words in ‚Äúquotes‚Äù).
To make a vector, we need to use the c() function



























NoteQuestion



What happens to the numbers in the my_numbers vector if you change 9 to 9.5?

title: Dataframes
text:
Dataframes
We‚Äôve looked at single values, and multiple values in a list. The next step is to look at tables of data - we can do this with dataframe. You‚Äôll commonly see this named as df for dataframe.








If you look in your environment (top right panel) you‚Äôll now see your Data_Frame variable. If you click it, this will open it in a new tab next to your R script.
We can use the built-in function summary() to create an overview of our data. For our numerical columns, this provides us with the interquartile range.

Summarise the data








This is already all the information we need to create a box plot!

title: Pearson‚Äôs coefficient: using cor()
text:
Pearson‚Äôs coefficient: using cor()
We can use two R functions to calculate our R and p values using a Pearson‚Äôs coefficient.
Our first example uses cor(). This gives us the R value - how strong is the correlation?

# Open heart.csv and save as a dataframe
heart_df <- read.csv("heart.csv") 

# Calculate R value from Pearson's coefficient
correlation_R_value <- cor(heart_df$age, heart_df$restbp, method = 'pearson')
# Print the R value calculated to the console (output)
correlation_R_value



[1] 0.2793509


Let‚Äôs break that down:

cor(heart_df$age, heart_df$restbp, method = 'pearson')

cor() : This is our function name. This is a built in function.
heart_df$age : This is going to our dataframe called heart_df and extracting the column of values under the column name ‚Äúage‚Äù
heart_df$restbp : This is going to our dataframe called heart_df and extracting the column of values under the column name ‚Äúrestbp‚Äù

method = 'pearson'

This is a parameter, which is an option to choose how we want the function to work.
We can set this to either 'pearson' or 'spearman' depending on which test we want to use.

title: Pearson‚Äôs coefficient: using cor.test()
text:
Pearson‚Äôs coefficient: using cor.test()
Our second example uses cor.test(). This gives us the R value - how strong is the correlation?

# Open heart.csv and save as a dataframe
heart_df <- read.csv("heart.csv") 

# Calculate correlation statistics using cor.test()
correlation_stats <- cor.test(heart_df$age, heart_df$restbp, method = 'pearson')

# Print the results to the console (output)
correlation_stats$p.value #print the p value 
correlation_stats$estimate #print the R value



[1] 7.762269e-07


      cor 
0.2793509 


As you can see that works very similarly to our first example, except for the last two lines.
cor.test() gives us a list of 9 values, there are only two we are interested in:

p.value is our probability p value
estimate is our correlation coefficient (R value, same as from the cor function)

title: Correlelograms
text:
Correlelograms
Our dataset contained more than just age and blood pressure - it would be useful to see if there are any correlations between e.g.¬†blood pressure and maximum heart rate, or cholesterol and age.
We can also use R to do an all-against-all correlation analysis, so without doing all of the above we can get an idea of if there are any correlations.
This uses the corrplot library. You might need to run install.packages('corrplot') before you can run this code.








Let‚Äôs break that down:

library(corrplot) is loading the corrplot package, which has the functions we need
heart_df_only_numerical <- heart_df[,-2]

Our sex in this dataframe is categorical (M or F) so we need to remove it
heart_df[,-2] is selecting the whole of the heart_df dataframe except column 2

heart_corrplot_matrix <- cor(heart_df_only_numerical)

This uses the cor() function to calculate all-against-all correlations

corrplot(heart_corrplot_matrix

This takes our all-against-all correlations and plots a correlelogram








TipTry:





Corrplot also has different settings you can use.
To plot the strength of the correlation (R value) numerically, try: corrplot(heart_corrplot_matrix, method = "number")
And if you only want to show the correlations that are statistically significant with a 5% chance of error:
corrplot(heart_corrplot_matrix, sig.level = 0.05)

title: Download CSV file
text:
Download CSV file
We have a file of data from an experiment on locusts. Download the file below, and move this to the same folder you have your R code. A csv file is like a plain excel table, but missing all the Microsoft formatting. This makes it easier for us to use.

  üì• Download LocustSerotonin.csv



The dataset we are going to use is LocustSerotonin.csv. This contains serotonin levels in the central nervous system of desert locusts that were experimentally crowded for 0 (the control group), 1, and 2 hours.
This data is from Chapter 2 of The Analysis of Biological Data.
This is a Dataset with 3 columns of data:

Locust Serotonin data columns and descriptions






Column
Data




serotoninLevel
Measurement of serotonin in individual locusts


treatmentTime
Amount of time being crowded (0, 1 or 2 hours)


serotoninCategory
Rank of serotonin level in three categories (High, Medium, Low)






African migratory locust. Image from Wikipedia
crumbs: R from Excel: Locust Serotonin levels

title: Anova
text:
Anova
Our final example is using our one-way ANOVA. We‚Äôre using the example of salaries and degrees - note that there‚Äôs not the same number of values for each group.









Create a dataframe
To do an ANOVA, we need to organise our data into a dataframe.














NoteQuestion





Why have we used c(9,7,9) here? What if you change these numbers around?
If you make a change, have a look at your Degrees_DataFrame values and see if they still match our original data.





Calculate the ANOVA p-value
We can calculate the ANOVA p-value by using the aov() function.








We use salary ~ group to assess salary as a function of the degree group.
We always put the response variable before the ~ and the explanation variable after. Another way of reading salary ~ group would be ‚ÄúSalary depends on degree group‚Äù

title: Extension
text:
Extension
This was a very large dataset and we only looked at a few columns.
What else can you find out?
Not all of the columns are categorical data - if you want to compare any other two variables (e.g.¬†whether they went to nursery and their current grades); which test would you use?
We‚Äôve covered all the main statistical tests now, so try and apply what you‚Äôve learnt from every tutorial to this database.



Meme of the Hulk being made for a Chi Squared test

title: Boxplot from file
text:
Boxplot from file
From the previous pages, we have a dataset with three columns:

Locust Serotonin data columns and descriptions






Column
Data




serotoninLevel
Measurement of serotonin in individual locusts


treatmentTime
Amount of time being crowded (0, 1 or 2 hours)


serotoninCategory
Rank of serotonin level in three categories (High, Medium, Low)



Next, we‚Äôre going to use boxplots to compare the serotonin level for different treatment groups.

# Load library
library(ggplot2)
# Import the CSV file into an R Dataframe
locust_df <- read.csv("LocustSerotonin.csv") 

# Plot the data using ggplot package
ggplot(locust_df, aes(x = treatmentTime, 
                      y = serotoninLevel, 
                      group = treatmentTime)) +
  geom_boxplot() 
















NoteQuestion



What happens if you remove group = treatmentTime from the above code? What is this doing?


Let‚Äôs break that down:

ggplot(locust_df, aes(x = treatmentTime, y = serotoninLevel, group = treatmentTime)):

ggplot() is the graphing function we are using
locust_df is the data we want to plot
aes() is our aesthetics - what is our x and y values?
group: Our treatmentTime column is a continuous data (as it is numerical). We want this to be discrete (three separate groups) so we explicity tell ggplot to organise this data into groups.

geom_boxplot(): this is specifying we want to plot a box plot of our data

title: Give it a go
text:
Give it a go
Can you change the code to make a boxplot of the Duration values? Fill in the values left as ______















NoteHint 1





The only parts you need to change is the aes() aesthetics, and ggtitle()










TipShow answer






# Libraries
library(ggplot2) # load ggplot2 libray 

# Create a Data Frame
Data_Frame <- data.frame (
  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", "Other"),
  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),
  Duration = c(60, 30, 45)
)

# Create a boxplot
ggplot(Data_Frame, aes(y = Duration)) +
  # add a colour argument
  geom_boxplot(fill = "lightgreen") + 
  #add a title 
  ggtitle("Duration boxplot") + 
  # Move title to the center
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5)) + 
  # Remove the gray background panel 
  theme(panel.background = element_blank()) # remove background

text:
Extension task
Correlation doesn‚Äôt always equal causation - and Spurious correlations has many examples to prove this.
If you go to the website and click on a correlation, you should get a table with the raw data.
You can then: 1. Copy and paste this table into excel 2. Save your excel spreadsheet as a CSV file 3. Read the CSV in R 4. Plot and test the correlations

Spurious correlatons

title: Contigency tables
text:
Contigency tables
First we need to read this information and store it in an R dataframe.








For our Chi-Squared and Fisher test however, we need to generate a contingency table. Effectively, we need to choose two categorical variables, and count the occurences of each combination. Luckily R will do this for us, using the table() function.
Let‚Äôs first look to see if there‚Äôs a difference between sex and whether the student does after-school activities.

title: Discrete verses continuous scale
text:
Discrete verses continuous scale
Here we have three distinct treatment groups. This is a discrete scale - no locusts were crowded for 1.5 hours for instance.

Continuous scaleDiscrete scale


As this is numerical, it‚Äôs automatically taken as a continuous scale. We can see this when we use fill = to colour the boxplots by treatmentTime.

library(ggplot2)
# Import the CSV file into an R Dataframe
locust_df <- read.csv("LocustSerotonin.csv") 

# Plot the data using ggplot package
ggplot(locust_df, aes(x = treatmentTime, 
                      y = serotoninLevel, 
                      group = treatmentTime, 
                      fill = treatmentTime)) +
  geom_boxplot() 












We can convert our dataframe column to a factor, which are variables that have a fixed and known set of possible values (categorical data).
To select a column from a dataframe, we can use $. So our treatmentTime column is locust_df$treatmentTime.
To turn a column of data from being continuous values to being discrete values, we can use the as.factor() function.
We can apply this to our treatmentTime values by using: as.factor(locust_df$treatmentTime)
Finally, if we just did the above it would convert our values to a factor but not save this. We can use <- to overwrite our original column which had the numerical values.
Putting that together we get:
locust_df$treatmentTime <- as.factor(locust_df$treatmentTime)

library(ggplot2)
# Import the CSV file into an R Dataframe
locust_df <- read.csv("LocustSerotonin.csv") 

# Convert treatment time column to discrete values
locust_df$treatmentTime <- as.factor(locust_df$treatmentTime)

# Plot the data using ggplot package
ggplot(locust_df, aes(x = treatmentTime, 
                      y = serotoninLevel, 
                      group = treatmentTime, 
                      fill = treatmentTime)) +
  geom_boxplot()

title: Violin plots
text:
Violin plots
Violin plots are similar to box plots, but they show more information on what the distribution is. A violin plot can sometimes give more useful information than a box plot.
To change from a box plot to a violin plot, you only need to change from geom_boxplot() to geom_violin().

library(ggplot2)
# Import the CSV file into an R Dataframe
locust_df <- read.csv("LocustSerotonin.csv") 

# Convert treatment time column to discrete values
locust_df$treatmentTime <- as.factor(locust_df$treatmentTime)

# Plot the data using ggplot package
ggplot(locust_df, aes(x = treatmentTime, 
                      y = serotoninLevel, 
                      group = treatmentTime, 
                      fill = treatmentTime)) +

  geom_violin() 










Question: If you add the line + geom_point(), what happens?
crumbs: R from Excel: Locust Serotonin levels

title: Annotate the R and p values onto the scatter graph
text:
To annotate our R and p values onto a scatter graph, we can use the stat_cor function from the ggpubr package.
If you‚Äôve not already installed it, make sure that first you install it in the console using:
install.packages('ggpubr')

# Load ggplot2 AND ggpubr packages
library(ggplot2)
library(ggpubr)

# Open heart.csv and save as a dataframe
heart_df <- read.csv("heart.csv") 

# Plot the heart data as before
ggplot(heart_df, aes(x = age, y = restbp)) +
  geom_point() +
  # add a pearson correlation from the stat_cor function
  stat_cor(method = 'pearson') 










The only parameter we used here for stat_cor was method = 'pearson' so that it would plot a pearson‚Äôs correlation.






NoteQuestion





Do the R and p values annotated on this graph match the results from cor.test()?





We can use parameters label.x and label.y to add co-ordinates for where we want the R and p value annotations to go.
Try it below:














Tip





If you‚Äôd like the R and p value to each be on their own line, we can add label.sep = '\n' which adds a \n newline character
What happens if you add label.sep = 'HELLO'?

title: Variables
text:
Variables
A variable is a box where we can store a value. This is important - if we calculate something in R, we‚Äôre going to want to be able to access the answer, so we need to store it somewhere.
See the below example - you can click Run Code to see what this does.








Let‚Äôs break that down:

a <- 5 + 10

a : This is our variable name. A variable is a piece of data with a name so we can find it again.
<- : This is an assignment operator; equivalent to ‚Äù = ‚Äú! It means the data on the right hand side is saved under the variable name on the left hand side
5 + 10 : Mathematical operations in R have a set format. If you want to multiply two numbers, you would use an asterix (*).

a

a : This line will get the value from our variable a, and print it to the console. It‚Äôs really useful for checking if a value is what you expect, especially when you have many variables!

title: Chi-squared test
text:
Chi-squared test
As our grand total of observed values is more than 50 and every observation exceeds 5, we can use the chi squared test.








As the p-value is 0.0597, it is not less than 0.05 and therefore not significant with less than a 5% chance of error.

title: Filtering data from a table
text:
Filtering data from a table

Filtering numerical dataFiltering categorical data


Lets say we want to filter our LocustSerotonin data to have only the 0 hour treatmentTime group.

library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)

# Import the CSV file into an R Dataframe
locust_df <- read.csv("LocustSerotonin.csv") 

# Filter for only values where treatmentTime is 0 
treatment0_df <- locust_df %>% filter(treatmentTime == 0)

# Make a histogram on this new dataframe
ggplot(treatment0_df, aes(x = serotoninLevel, group = treatmentTime, 
                      fill = treatmentTime)) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 0.6)










Let‚Äôs break that down:

We‚Äôre using functions from the dplyr package. You need to install by typing install.packages('dplyr') if you haven‚Äôt already.
We‚Äôre using the filter() function to select all rows where treatmentTime is exactly 0. Be sure to notice the double ==!
%>% is a pipe - it‚Äôs telling R to pass the dataset on the left (locust_df) to the function on the right (filter())
We don‚Äôt want to overwrite our full dataset, so we‚Äôre saving in a new dataframe called treatment0_df using <- .







NoteQuestion



Can you create a dataset with only the treatmentTime values that are more than 0?




We can also select for string (words and letter) values. This is the same, except that we need to put any strings in quotes " " as in the below example.

library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)

# Import the CSV file into an R Dataframe
locust_df <- read.csv("LocustSerotonin.csv") 

# Filter for only values where serotoninCategory is "Medium"
MediumSerotonin_df <- locust_df %>% filter(serotoninCategory == "Medium")

# Plot a histogram for this dataset
ggplot(MediumSerotonin_df, aes(x = serotoninLevel, group = treatmentTime, 
                      fill = treatmentTime)) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 0.6)

title: Pairwise t test results
text:
Our ANOVA was significant - but now we need to know which pairs are significantly different.
We can use pairwise.t.test() to do a t-test for all pairs of groups in our dataset.








We use the options:

pool.sd = FALSE so that variance is calculated independantly for each group
p.adjust.method = "none" as this function by default uses a Holm-Bonferroni correction to minimize false positives which is beyond the scope of this course.



We can create a boxplot and plot all of our pairwise comparison p values.
To do this, first we can create a list containing all the pairs we want to plot the p-value for. Remember you only need to do each pair once - if you have c("Economics", "History") you don‚Äôt also need c("History", "Economics").

text:

title: One-tailed t-test
text:
We can follow the same process for the one-tailed t-test. First, we need our list of grades from our example.










We can use the summary() function to see our mean and interquartile range for each set of values.











Using the function t.test(), we can add our one set of values and the number we want to compare it to. In this example, we‚Äôre looking to see if our mean value is greater than 40.
We need to specify the option alternative = 'greater' to do a one-tailed test for if the mean of our Grades are significantly above our value for mu, which we have set to 40 (a pass).











Because we only have one group of data values, we can create our dataframe and draw our boxplot very simply.








We don‚Äôt need to annotate our p-value on here - it wouldn‚Äôt make much sense to do so as our p-value was specifically assessing if the mean was higher than 40 which is hard to represent visually.

title: Plotting age verses resting blood pressure
text:
Plotting age verses resting blood pressure
We could speculate that resting blood pressure may increase with age. To plot this, we can use the ggplot function geom_point.
Using aes() we can choose to plot age on the x axis, and resting blood pressure on the y axis. Make sure your x = ______ matches the column title in the dataframe.

library(ggplot2)

heart_df <- read.csv("heart.csv") 

ggplot(heart_df, aes(x = age, y = restbp)) +
  geom_point()
crumbs: Plotting age verses resting blood pressure

title: GGstyle
text:
GGstyle
We can use the + to add new lines to our graph. This allows us to add more styling information.
You want a + at the end of every line until the last one. This tells R where you want to stop and move on.

# Load ggplot2 library
library(ggplot2) 

# Create a data frame
Data_Frame <- data.frame (
  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", "Other"),
  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),
  Duration = c(60, 30, 45)
)

# Create a boxplot of pulse
ggplot(Data_Frame, aes(y = Pulse)) +
  # add a colour argument
  geom_boxplot(fill = "lightblue") + 
  #add a title 
  ggtitle("Pulse boxplot") + 
  # Move title to the center
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5)) + 
  # Remove the gray background panel 
  theme(panel.background = element_blank()) # remove background








Check out this ggplot2 cheat sheet for more styling options

title: Portugese students data
text:
Portugese students data
For this tutorial we need the ‚Äústudent-mat.csv‚Äù file from the canvas page. This is from a study looking factors that may affect maths students at a school in Portugal, which includes lots of categorical data.
This dataset contains the following information about each student:

title: Chi-squared with multiple categories
text:
Chi-squared with multiple categories
Finally, let‚Äôs look at an example with multiple categories in one of the variables.
Perhaps there is a difference between the reasons students chose the school and which school they attend.

# Create a contigency table for school verses reason 
maths_students=read.csv("student-mat.csv", header=TRUE)

school_by_reason <- table(maths_students$school, maths_students$reason)
school_by_reason



    
     course home other reputation
  GP    124   98    27        100
  MS     21   11     9          5


We can then run the chi-squared test exactly the same as before:

# Calculate the chi squared test 
chisq <- chisq.test(school_by_reason)

# Print a table of observations
chisq$observed

    
     course home other reputation
  GP    124   98    27        100
  MS     21   11     9          5

# Print a table of expected values
chisq$expected

    
        course     home     other reputation
  GP 128.11392 96.30633 31.807595   92.77215
  MS  16.88608 12.69367  4.192405   12.22785

# Print the p-value
chisq$p.value

[1] 0.005947834


The p-value is 0.00595 (is this less than 0.05?)
We can visualise which factors had the biggest contribution to the result by doing the following calculation:
\(100 \times \frac{residuals^2}{statistic}\)
We can then visualise this with corrplot.

library(corrplot)

# Run calculation of contributions
contrib <- 100*chisq$residuals^2/chisq$statistic

# Visualise with corrplot
corrplot(contrib, is.cor = FALSE)

title: Install packages
text:
Install packages
For the rest of the worksheet section, we need to install a package
In R we use many packages - these are extensions that contain the code we need to do cool things like plot graphs. There are many packages available for different uses, which means you don‚Äôt have to write everything from scratch!
Install the packages ggplot2 which we will be using. In the console (bottom left corner), copy and paste the following line and press enter:
install.packages('ggplot2')
Once it is installed, we can load the package into our R file using the line:
library(ggplot2)

title: Bar charts and histograms
text:
Bar charts and histograms

Bar charts by countsHistograms


Sometimes we don‚Äôt want to use numerical values (such as the serotonin level) that we already have in our dataset. If we want to plot the numbers of our categories we can make a bar chart like in the below example:

library(ggplot2)

# Import the CSV file into an R Dataframe
locust_df <- read.csv("LocustSerotonin.csv") 

# Set factor levels with factor() function
locust_df$serotoninCategory <- factor(locust_df$serotoninCategory, levels = c("High", "Medium", "Low"))

# Use geom_bar(stat='count') to create bar chart
ggplot(locust_df, aes(x = treatmentTime, fill = serotoninCategory)) +
         geom_bar(stat = 'count')










Here we have:

Set locust_df$serotoninCategory as a factor with levels. This was to order our graph. What happens if you comment this out?
Used geom_bar(stat = 'count') - for each category on the x axis, this counts the number of entries. Without using fill, this would just make a bar of height 10 for all three groups, as there was equal numbers of each treatment group.
The fill is used to colour the sections by serotonin category.



We can also draw histograms using geom_histogram to visualise distributions.

library(ggplot2)
# Import the CSV file into an R Dataframe
locust_df <- read.csv("LocustSerotonin.csv") 

# Plot a histogram grouped by treatmentTime
ggplot(locust_df, aes(x = serotoninLevel, group = treatmentTime, 
                      fill = treatmentTime)) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 0.6)
















Note



What is binwidth = 0.6 doing? What changes if you remove this? What if you make this value smaller or larger?


Is this a normal distribution?

title: Boxplot
text:
Boxplot
Now we‚Äôve installed ggplot2, we can use it to make a box plot from our data frame.

# Load ggplot2 library
library(ggplot2) 

# Create a data frame
Data_Frame <- data.frame (
  Training = c("Strength", "Stamina", "Other"),
  Pulse = c(100, 150, 120),
  Duration = c(60, 30, 45)
)

# Create a boxplot of Pulse values
ggplot(Data_Frame, aes(y = Pulse)) +
  geom_boxplot() 








Do the values match what we got in the summary() function?
Let‚Äôs break that down:

ggplot(Data_Frame, aes(y = Pulse)) +

ggplot() : This is our plotting function
Data_Frame: This is our argument of what data we want to use
aes(): aes is aesthetics, which allows us to choose our groups for x, y or categories
y = Pulse: this is setting our y value to be the pulse column

geom_boxplot()

This tells R to use the data we chose to make a boxplot

title: Odds and Risk ratios
text:
We can calculate the odds ratio for our comparison using the oddsratio() function from the epitools package.
You‚Äôll first need to install.packages('epitools').








This result shows us the odds of male students doing an activity (compared to females) is 1.491 -> they are around 1.5 times more likely to be doing an activity.
Also in this table are the ‚Äúlower‚Äù and ‚Äúupper‚Äù values are the boundaries for the 95% confidence interval. As both values are above one, this indicates increased odds (of males doing an activity compared to females).
We can do the same calculation the other way around, looking at the odds of females doing an activity compared to males.








The options you can give for the rev (reverse) parameter are ‚Äúneither‚Äù, ‚Äúrows‚Äù, ‚Äúcolumns‚Äù and ‚Äúboth‚Äù.



Risk ratio is very similar to odds ratio (refer back to Statistics Lecture 4 for an explanation of the differences).
We can also calculate risk ratio in R.








This shows the risk of males doing an activity (compared to females) is 1.217.

title: Penguins dataset introduction
text:
Penguins dataset introduction
For this set of tasks, you will need the penguins.csv file.

  üì• Download penguins.csv



This is data from a study which looked at penguin couples. Once a penguin pair had laid an egg, both parents were captured and measurements were taken. They were then tracked to see if they would go on to have a second egg or ‚ÄúFull Clutch‚Äù.
This dataset contains the following information:

Penguins data columns and descriptions


Column
Data

Unique number for every penguin

Species name, full Latin name

Whether or not the penguin couple laid two eggs


FlipperLength
Length of the penguin‚Äôs flipper in millimeters


BodyMass
Mass of the penguin in grams


Sex
Whether the penguin is male or female



And is looking at penguins of the following three species:






Adelie Penguin







Chinstrap Penguin







Gentoo Penguin





To process this data using R, using the techniques you‚Äôve covered so far, this has been split into 5 small tasks.

title: Welcome to R Programming!
text:
The next 5 computing sessions are going to introduce you to R programming. This is a computer language very commonly used in Life Sciences to do statistical analyses and interpret large data sets.
Don‚Äôt worry if you‚Äôve never done any programming before - we‚Äôre starting from the very beginning.


Advances in Life Sciences has let to the creation of terrabytes of Big Data. We can now sequence millions of bases of DNA, calculate expression levels of thousands of proteins and track the movements of whales around the world.
In order to be able to make sense of these large datasets, we use programming languages. It would be quite difficult to calculate a statistically significant result if your dataset has more than 1000 values!



Below is a table of a recent publication for each subject which used R in the analysis - quite varied!

Life Science R Programming Examples. Images from Google and Adobe Stock







Degree
Paper title
Icon




Biomedical Science
Pediatric leukemia and maternal occupational exposure to anticancer drugs: the Japan Environment and Children‚Äôs Study



Biochemistry
The ORP9-ORP11 dimer promotes sphingomyelin synthesis



Biological Science
Humpback whale song complexity and evolution on a northwestern Pacific breeding ground: Okinawa, Japan



Pharmacology
Explaining Blood‚ÄìBrain Barrier Permeability of Small Molecules by Integrated Analysis of Different Transport Mechanisms



Forensic Science
An Open-Source Implementation of the CMPS Algorithm for Assessing Similarity of Bullets







This course is your first introduction to R.
Next year (Level 5), most of you will continue R programming in Research Methods and Skills. Forensic Science students will use other Statistical Analysis software.
In your final year (Level 6) you will all do a research project - this may be in the lab, a literature review or data project. R programming can be used for analysis of your research data in all of these projects.
Biological Science (Molecular Biology) and Biochemistry students will also do a Python-programming module at Level 6. This builds on what you know from R.



First get yourself set up with R and RStudio - click the ‚ÄúSet Up‚Äù tab for instructions.
Next start the classes under the ‚ÄúLearn‚Äù tab. This is all of the material for the five sessions - you can work through them at your own pace.
Each page will cover a new concept, or have an activity on for you to try. As you work through, try to experiment - change parts of the code examples and see if it will still work. This is how you figure out how it works.
If you have any other questions, grab a member of teaching staff in the session or email Dr Lizzie Wadsworth at L.Wadsworth@kingston.ac.uk

title: Help
text:
Help
Stuck? That‚Äôs normal! Learning programming is like learning a language, it takes a lot of time and you don‚Äôt start fluent.
Email Lizzie for support L.Wadsworth@kingston.ac.uk; it can help to send a screenshot or your .R file - every error is unique so the more information you can provide the quicker we can figure out the issue.
Find below a list of common error messages. This will be updated throughout the teaching block as you send me the error messages you are getting.

title: Set up
text:
Set up
We are going to use RStudio for this course. You can do this on campus from a University Computer, online using a free Posit Cloud account that you can access from any web browser, or by downloading R and RStudio onto your own device.

title: Open CSV file in R
text:
Open CSV file in R
Once you‚Äôve moved the LocustSerotonin.csv to your R programming folder, you can then open this in your R file. We can do this using functions:

Use the function read.csv() to import our data into R as a dataframe. This will appear in the environment (top right panel) with our variables.
Use the function head() to view the first five rows of our table.


locust_df <- read.csv("LocustSerotonin.csv") 
head(locust_df)



  serotoninLevel treatmentTime serotoninCategory
1            5.3             0            Medium
2            4.6             0               Low
3            4.5             0               Low
4            4.3             0               Low
5            4.2             0               Low
6            3.6             0               Low


We can also view our dataframe by clicking the variable locust_df in the environment tab (top right panel).



Move CSV to folder and open and run file in R
crumbs: R from Excel: Locust Serotonin levels

title: Discrete verses continuous scale
text:
To select a column from a dataframe, we can use $. So our treatmentTime column is locust_df$treatmentTime.
To turn a column of data from being continuous values to being discrete values, we can use the as.factor() function.
We can apply this to our treatmentTime values by using: as.factor(locust_df$treatmentTime)
Finally, if we just did the above it would convert our values to a factor but not save this. We can use <- to overwrite our original column which had the numerical values.
Putting that together we get:
locust_df$treatmentTime <- as.factor(locust_df$treatmentTime)

library(ggplot2)
# Import the CSV file into an R Dataframe
locust_df <- read.csv("LocustSerotonin.csv") 

# Convert treatment time column to discrete values
locust_df$treatmentTime <- as.factor(locust_df$treatmentTime)

# Plot the data using ggplot package
ggplot(locust_df, aes(x = treatmentTime, 
                      y = serotoninLevel, 
                      group = treatmentTime, 
                      fill = treatmentTime)) +
  geom_boxplot()
crumbs: R from Excel: Locust Serotonin levels

title: Bar charts and histograms
text:
We can also draw histograms using geom_histogram to visualise distributions.

library(ggplot2)
# Import the CSV file into an R Dataframe
locust_df <- read.csv("LocustSerotonin.csv") 

# Plot a histogram grouped by treatmentTime
ggplot(locust_df, aes(x = serotoninLevel, group = treatmentTime, 
                      fill = treatmentTime)) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 0.6)
















Note



What is binwidth = 0.6 doing? What changes if you remove this? What if you make this value smaller or larger?


Is this a normal distribution?
crumbs: R from Excel: Locust Serotonin levels

title: Bar charts and histograms
text:
Sometimes we don‚Äôt want to use numerical values (such as the serotonin level) that we already have in our dataset. If we want to plot the numbers of our categories we can make a bar chart like in the below example:

library(ggplot2)

# Import the CSV file into an R Dataframe
locust_df <- read.csv("LocustSerotonin.csv") 

# Set factor levels with factor() function
locust_df$serotoninCategory <- factor(locust_df$serotoninCategory, levels = c("High", "Medium", "Low"))

# Use geom_bar(stat='count') to create bar chart
ggplot(locust_df, aes(x = treatmentTime, fill = serotoninCategory)) +
         geom_bar(stat = 'count')










Here we have:

Set locust_df$serotoninCategory as a factor with levels. This was to order our graph. What happens if you comment this out?
Used geom_bar(stat = 'count') - for each category on the x axis, this counts the number of entries. Without using fill, this would just make a bar of height 10 for all three groups, as there was equal numbers of each treatment group.
The fill is used to colour the sections by serotonin category.
crumbs: R from Excel: Locust Serotonin levels

title: Filtering data from a table
text:
Lets say we want to filter our LocustSerotonin data to have only the 0 hour treatmentTime group.

library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)

# Import the CSV file into an R Dataframe
locust_df <- read.csv("LocustSerotonin.csv") 

# Filter for only values where treatmentTime is 0 
treatment0_df <- locust_df %>% filter(treatmentTime == 0)

# Make a histogram on this new dataframe
ggplot(treatment0_df, aes(x = serotoninLevel, group = treatmentTime, 
                      fill = treatmentTime)) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 0.6)




Attaching package: 'dplyr'


The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    filter, lag


The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    intersect, setdiff, setequal, union


  serotoninLevel treatmentTime serotoninCategory
1            5.3             0            Medium
2            4.6             0               Low
3            4.5             0               Low
4            4.3             0               Low
5            4.2             0               Low
6            3.6             0               Low


Let‚Äôs break that down:

We‚Äôre using functions from the dplyr package. You need to install by typing install.packages('dplyr') if you haven‚Äôt already.
We‚Äôre using the filter() function to select all rows where treatmentTime is exactly 0. Be sure to notice the double ==!
%>% is a pipe - it‚Äôs telling R to pass the dataset on the left (locust_df) to the function on the right (filter())
We don‚Äôt want to overwrite our full dataset, so we‚Äôre saving in a new dataframe called treatment0_df using <- .







NoteQuestion



Can you create a dataset with only the treatmentTime values that are more than 0?

title: Filtering data from a table
text:
We can also select for string (words and letter) values. This is the same, except that we need to put any strings in quotes " " as in the below example.

library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)

# Import the CSV file into an R Dataframe
locust_df <- read.csv("LocustSerotonin.csv") 

# Filter for only values where serotoninCategory is "Medium"
MediumSerotonin_df <- locust_df %>% filter(serotoninCategory == "Medium")

# Plot a histogram for this dataset
ggplot(MediumSerotonin_df, aes(x = serotoninLevel, group = treatmentTime, 
                      fill = treatmentTime)) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 0.6)

title: Extension 2: Larger penguin dataset
text:
Extension 2: Larger penguin dataset
If you finish all of the above and would like to challenge your skills, download the Penguins_extension.csv.

This is the same dataset but with more columns:

Penguins extension data columns and descriptions


Column

Unique number for every penguin

Common name for the penguin species

Region of Antartica the penguin is in

Island of Antartica the penguin‚Äôs nest is in

Whether or not the penguin couple laid two eggs


EggDate
Date at which the first egg was laid


CulmenLength
Length of the penguin‚Äôs culmen in millimeters


CulmenDepth
Depth of the penguin‚Äôs culmen in millimeters


FlipperLength
Length of the penguin‚Äôs flipper in millimeters


BodyMass
Mass of the penguin in grams


Sex
Whether the penguin is male or female









NoteDealing with dates





One column of this dataset is dates. By default these will be treated as strings - as words with no set order.
This means that dates won‚Äôt be plotted in order from oldest to newest, which is not very useful.
To convert our dates into a ‚ÄúDate‚Äù class - to tell R that these are dates - we can use the following code:

penguin_df$EggDate <- as.Date(penguin_df$EggDate, format = "%d/%m/%y")




At this point, it‚Äôs up to you what you want to do - explore the data! What can you find out? Are there any patterns emerging?
